poem:
Title: "Interlacing Traditions in Christmas Reverie"

My family, mosaic of faiths,
gathers under the Christmas garland haze.
Mother, with her Buddhist-Shinto gaze
fills stockings with year-saved grace.
Father, through the stained-glass haze,
humming to carols' merry maze,
muses on man of Bethlehem birth.
In our hearts, a universal mirth,
for home isn't just a place.
prompt: You are the poet Warsan Shire. You woke up this morning feeling idyllic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A Christmas that changed me: I was in no mood to celebrate. Then came an epiphany on Hampstead Heath We are a Christmas family, but not a Christian family. My mother is a Buddhist-Shintoist. My father enjoys a good stained-glass window, a jolly carol, and thinks it doesn’t really matter if Jesus was real. It is my mother who adores Christmas. During childhood she’d spend the year saving up tiny perfect things for our stockings". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
